Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Development of 13C-assisted Metabolic Flux Analysis Tools for Metabolic Engineering of Cyanobacteria

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
Cyanobacteria possess a complex and unique network for carbon metabolism, enabling them to thrive on the minimal nutrients available in aquatic environments. This research develops and applies 13C-assisted metabolic flux analysis tools to study photoautotrophic metabolism in the model cyanobacteria Synechocystis sp. PCC6803 and Cyanothece 51142. The research objectives include: 1) improving GC-MS-based metabolite and isotopomer (isotopic isomer) measurement techniques, 2) developing a dynamic flux model to decipher carbon fluxes and metabolic regulation based on isotopomer distribution in fast-turnover metabolites, 3) applying the flux model for metabolic engineering of cyanobacteria to synthesize butanol via non-fermentative pathways. This research will generate 13C-assisted flux analysis tools to understand enzyme functions and metabolic regulations in cyanobacteria. This study will also develop strains to produce biofuels from carbon dioxide and sunlight.

Broader Impacts

This project explores cyanobacterial applications, offering a potential solution to both energy and environmental crises. The 13C-assisted flux analysis tools developed in this project can be used to investigate many other photosynthetic organisms including plants used for commercial agriculture. Furthermore, research and education efforts will be combined through the following: 1) Two biotechnology courses (Bioprocess Laboratory and Synthetic Biology) will be created to improve both biological laboratory skills and bioscience knowledge for undergraduate students; 2) the CAREER research will be integrated with the Washington University iGEM (International Genetically Engineered Machine Competition) team project, encouraging participation of female/minority students; 3) the CAREER research will be integrated with the Clean-Coal Program at Washington University (supported by local companies in St. Louis) to provide students with industrial experience.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Final Project Report (Award Number: 0954016; amount $500,000)

CAREER: Development of 13C-assisted Metabolic Flux Analysis Tools for Metabolic Engineering of Cyanobacteria

In this CAREER project, the Tang Lab has developed and applied 13C-Metabolic Flux Analysis tools (13C-MFA) for characterizing two cyanobacterial species (non-nitrogen-fixing Synechocystis 6803 and nitrogen-fixing Cyanothece 51142). We examined autotrophic, mixotrophic and heterotrophic metabolisms the two cyanobacterial species. In Cyanothece 51142, we measured cell carbon utilizations under both nitrogen sufficient and nitrogen deficient conditions. Our study indicated that glycerol improves biomass growth and hydrogen generations in Cyanothece 51142. In addition, we re-visited the TCA cycle in Synechocystis 6803, which revealed that Synechocystis 6803 did not employ significant flux through a complete TCA cycle, even though newly discovered enzymes are reported to close its TCA cycle. We also found that the oxidative pentose phosphate pathway in Synechocystis 6803 is flexible, which can be highly up-regulated under light limiting condition or photoheterotrophic condition. Guided by 13C-metabolism analysis, we rationally engineered Synechocystis 6803 as cyanobacterial factories for producing biofuel (biobutanol) and polymer building blocks (D-lactate). Note: we are the first lab in the world that reported engineered cyanobacteria for D-lactate biosynthesis.

 

The outcomes have significant intellectual merits. This project has developed a few useful tools for metabolism analysis. First, we invented a simple 13C-fingerprinting method and tool kits that can use multiple 13C-substrates to generate unique labeling patterns in proteinogenic amino acids. This method provides a quick and cost-effective way to reveal active pathways in nonmodel microorganisms. Second, we developed 13C-MFA model platform to measure microbial metabolism (http://13cmfa.org/). We also built a web based platform to facilitate the metabolic model constructions (http://www.microbesflux.org/). Third, we built a dynamic flux balance analysis to predict cyanobacterial physiology by integrating bioreactor hydrodynamics, light distributions, CO2 mass transfer, and growth kinetics. We are continuing to improve our GC-MS protocol and modeling development after the end of the CAREER project.

 

This project has broader impact. We have provided our 13C-metabolism analysis for many other research labs and help them characterize nonmodel microbial species (>20). In addition, we provided experimental and modeling protocols on websites or through articles in peer-reviewed journals. On the other hand, the Tang Lab had significant educational efforts and outreaches to high school students and undergraduate/graduate students. First, PI Tang developed two new courses at WUSTL (Bioprocess Engineering and Metabolic Engineering). Second, PI Tang mentored the iGEM team in 2010 summer (won a silver medal). Third, the Lab offered hands-on research training for undergraduate students in the past five years (total 12 students; four of them entered PhD programs in top universities; six of them published papers with PI Tang). We also have hosted five high school students (four female students and one African American student) for their summer research experience. Finally, this NSF grant supported three PhD students: Xueyang Feng (2010~2011, currently Assistant Professor at Virginia Tech); Arul Varman (2011~2013, currently Postdoc at Sandia National Lab); Le Yo...
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: Final Project Report (Award Number: 0954016; amount $500,000) CAREER: Development of 13C-assisted Metabolic Flux Analysis Tools for Metabolic Engineering of Cyanobacteria In this CAREER project, the Tang Lab has developed and applied 13C-Metabolic Flux Analysis tools (13C-MFA) for characterizing two cyanobacterial species (non-nitrogen-fixing Synechocystis 6803 and nitrogen-fixing Cyanothece 51142). We examined autotrophic, mixotrophic and heterotrophic metabolisms the two cyanobacterial species. In Cyanothece 51142, we measured cell carbon utilizations under both nitrogen sufficient and nitrogen deficient conditions. Our study indicated that glycerol improves biomass growth and hydrogen generations in Cyanothece 51142. In addition, we re-visited the TCA cycle in Synechocystis 6803, which revealed that Synechocystis 6803 did not employ significant flux through a complete TCA cycle, even though newly discovered enzymes are reported to close its TCA cycle. We also found that the oxidative pentose phosphate pathway in Synechocystis 6803 is flexible, which can be highly up-regulated under light limiting condition or photoheterotrophic condition. Guided by 13C-metabolism analysis, we rationally engineered Synechocystis 6803 as cyanobacterial factories for producing biofuel (biobutanol) and polymer building blocks (D-lactate). Note: we are the first lab in the world that reported engineered cyanobacteria for D-lactate biosynthesis. The outcomes have significant intellectual merits. This project has developed a few useful tools for metabolism analysis. First, we invented a simple 13C-fingerprinting method and tool kits that can use multiple 13C-substrates to generate unique labeling patterns in proteinogenic amino acids. This method provides a quick and cost-effective way to reveal active pathways in nonmodel microorganisms. Second, we developed 13C-MFA model platform to measure microbial metabolism (http://13cmfa.org/). We also built a web based platform to facilitate the metabolic model constructions (http://www.microbesflux.org/). Third, we built a dynamic flux balance analysis to predict cyanobacterial physiology by integrating bioreactor hydrodynamics, light distributions, CO2 mass transfer, and growth kinetics. We are continuing to improve our GC-MS protocol and modeling development after the end of the CAREER project. This project has broader impact. We have provided our 13C-metabolism analysis for many other research labs and help them characterize nonmodel microbial species (>20). In addition, we provided experimental and modeling protocols on websites or through articles in peer-reviewed journals. On the other hand, the Tang Lab had significant educational efforts and outreaches to high school students and undergraduate/graduate students. First, PI Tang developed two new courses at WUSTL (Bioprocess Engineering and Metabolic Engineering). Second, PI Tang mentored the iGEM team in 2010 summer (won a silver medal). Third, the Lab offered hands-on research training for undergraduate students in the past five years (total 12 students; four of them entered PhD programs in top universities; six of them published papers with PI Tang). We also have hosted five high school students (four female students and one African American student) for their summer research experience. Finally, this NSF grant supported three PhD students: Xueyang Feng (2010~2011, currently Assistant Professor at Virginia Tech); Arul Varman (2011~2013, currently Postdoc at Sandia National Lab); Le You (2014~2015, currently Postdoc at University of California, San Diego). We will continue our missions to promote both research and educations in advanced biology fields. Last Modified: 04/01/2015 Submitted by: Yinjie Tang
